Description: Hollow terracotta votive offering in the form of Harpokrates, apparently naked, seated on a throne, the arms of which are supported by frontal Sothic dogs with collars and surmounted by small couchant lions; between the dogs a cobra supports Harpokrates’ feet with its uraeus-and-disc Hathor crown. The god has luxuriant hair with a Double Crown above and has his left hand to his mouth; his right hand holds a lotus bud to his shoulder. He may have a pendant at his breast, and wears anklets and bracelets. Details of the construction of the throne are indicated both on its front and back. Flat-faced plinth with horizontal grooves. Two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with white inclusions. Traces of a white dressing on front and sides.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired in the Fayum. Roman, first or second century AD. Comparandum: Not unlike, with sphinxes rather than Sothic dogs: Perdrizet 1921: no. 304. Bibliog: Budge 1925: pl. xxviii.
